text:
What's hot From Kyunki's 120-year-old Baa to the talking portrait in Hum Paanch; these TV characters are unbelievable, to say the least Unbelievable characters and Indian television share a deep and hilarious bond. Here are some of our favourite 'unbelievable' characters from Indian shows. A + A - Sudha Shivpuri as Baa in Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi. Picture courtesy: YouTube 
Indian television is full of unbelievable characters. And we don't mean that in a good way. Okay, a couple of characters in this particular listicle are legendary. And we will NEVER forget them, but that does not take away from the fact that we had a hard time believing them. 
Here are five such characters: 
Baa from Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi A still from the show Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi. Picture courtesy: YouTube 
Baa, played by Sudha Shivpuri, was the head of the Virani family, and she loved to sit on her rocking chair and preach about relationships to her huge family. She bonded particularly well with Tulsi, the protagonist of the show. But what makes her unbelievable, you ask? 
She was 120. Or maybe 125. No one really knows (or cares), but the fact is that she was too old to be alive, to be brutally honest. The show took leaps, characters were killed off, characters were introduced. But Baa, Baa remained the constant driving force of the moralistic family. 
Rancho from Raja aur Rancho 
The show was an instant hit in the late 90s. And perhaps the major contributing factor to the show's success was Rancho aka the assistant monkey who helped Raja, the main man, solve crimes. Yes, he was adorable, and it was funny. And monkeys are intelligent beings, but solving crimes is taking it to the next level altogether. 
Anand Mathur's first wife in Hum Paanch A promo poster of the show. Picture courtesy: YouTube 
Yes, we are talking about the, well, the talking portrait, who was also the first wife of the character Anand Mathur in the show. Played by Priya Tendulkar, the portrait was as much a character of the comedy series as any. The only hitch is that she had died, and she continued to haunt her husband from her portrait. 
Of course, we enjoyed it all; Mr Mathur's frustration, the portrait's comic timing; but the bottom line is that this does not happen in real life. 
Farooq Sheikh's character in Chamatkar 
A man who can 'hear' people's thoughts. A mind-reader. That is what the veteran actor's character was capable of in the show. It was hilarious, but we had a hard time believing our protagonist. 
Tanu in Kasam Tere Pyaar Ki 
Tanu (Kratika Sengar) falls in love with a perfect guy (Rishi aka Ssharad Malhotra), Tanu dies. Tanu takes birth again to claim her love, Karz style. We will just leave it at that. 
In fact, the promo of the show pretty much revealed that the serial's basic plot was all about reincarnations, rebirths, and lost loves.
